Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea,"

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot enabled by default using a key provided by Microsoft. Concerns were raised that secure boot could prevent or hinder the use of alternate operating systems such as Linux. In a post discussing secure boot on the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste indicated that vendors would provide means to customize secure boot, stating that "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide means for users to re-configure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps." By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree species. John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment.

The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. The sides of the field are marked by white sidelines, the goal line is marked in white, and white lines are drawn laterally across the field every 5 yards (4.6 m) from the goal line. These lateral lines are called "yard lines" and often marked with the distance in yards from and an arrow

In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum (for example, most of the Midwestern U.S.). The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. The Bush administration then turned its attention to Iraq, and argued the need to remove Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq had become urgent. Among the stated reasons were that Iraq was believed to have weapons of mass destruction, had been involved in a scheme to assassinate the former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, was engaged in support for terrorism, and posed a threat to U.S., Israeli and other regional interests.

However, as we explained in our book ‘The Iraq War: A History‘, none of those allegations about Iraq’s WMD were true. Moreover, the only ‘evidence’ of the latter two allegations did not lead to investigations or charges in domestic courts. As for the other claims, there is no evidence that Saddam intended to kill Annan to frame him and then assassinate him. The evidence is to the contrary, and a number of other states with which Iraq had diplomatic relations disagreed about the claims (see p57).

An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the environment in which we live is different for everyone based on, among other things, socio-economic class, access to the arts, parental education levels, family size and family structure. However, there is a gap in the body of research about what adolescents think of themselves. The question that drives this study is: which identities do Latino adolescents identify with? In order to answer this question, a content analysis was performed on the self-generated descriptions of five Latino adolescents in the United States. This paper explores the characteristics of the self-identified identities the children expressed, and then describes how these results differ between children and their mothers, mothers and their children, and siblings. The participants' stories illustrate the complexity of the lived and lived in spaces in which Latino adolescents grow up.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two in the U.S., and two at a neutral site location.

Most teams have just one pre-season game per year, usually against a team from the same division. So, teams in the playoffs or trying to make the Super Bowl face a different team from every division, and face five divisional teams, including three divisional opponents twice.

Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, not least because many were published by Private Eye. It is little wonder, therefore, that the House of Windsor was the subject of two TV satire series in 1983.

But these satirical series are part of a vast tradition of royal satire stretching back decades and not confined to the BBC. In this article I will explore the history of royal satire and focus on the British royal family, but I am aware that royal satire has at times been an international affair. I will also examine the current status of the TV satire genre, with particular focus on the royal family.

The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 cubic metres of cubic stone.[9] The exterior walls of the palace consist of a double wall of sandstone about 4 metres (13 feet) thick,[30] of which only half is visible from outside. This is built from limestone with ashlars from different local limestone quarries in the same size and shape. The masonry is divided into courses of regular sized blocks with occasional "keyhole" openings for the insertion of wooden wedges under the stones.[31] The keystone method of construction was used with wedge and keyhole.

Although the walls have stood for at least a thousand years, the palace is still very well preserved. To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in the 17th and 18th centuries. His military campaigns led to the total elimination of the Dzungar threat and to the creation of the Qing Empire's first modern standing army and navy. By the time of the Qianlong Emperor, the Qing state enjoyed its greatest influence and territory in its history. Under the leadership of the Qianlong Emperor, Qing China was the dominant power in Central Asia and the Qing dynasty controlled roughly one-sixth of all the territory in the world.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and a host of others, was among the most significant contributions to early Black Studies. It was a critical intervention, the likes of which had not been seen before in Black Studies, and in social studies more broadly. His work in the 1980s and 1990s marked the start of a renaissance of the field. Yet it was the work they and countless others have done before – from W. E. B. Du Bois to the Black Panther Party to Huey Newton – that has made this recent period particularly fertile and exciting. What I want to argue in the remainder of this essay is that the legacy of Black studies can be seen in the works of a figure as diverse – in terms of his subject matter as in his approach – as Hall. Libya's economy witnessed increasing privatization; although rejecting the socialist policies of nationalized industry advocated in The Green Book, government figures asserted that they were forging ahead with a market model inspired by that document. In fact, some of these reforms reflected a more traditional pattern of private sector development, following the lead of other Arab countries like Morocco and Iraq, where some private sector activity had begun before the revolution. The main change, however, was the abandonment of the public sector altogether. In the 1980s, total government revenue exceeded total government expenditure by almost one third of the national annual budget, while nationalized industries accounted for more than half of the value added in the state sector.

Since the end of the eighties, this gap has been reduced dramatically, so that at the time of the revolution, the ratios had been nearly inverted, with state expenditure accounting for more than half of gross national product, while private sector activity was about 1.7 percent. More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to form coalitions, as is the case with the United States or the United Kingdom, for example. Coalitions come in many different varieties, and parties are likely to win parliamentary seats for all sorts of reasons. They might be from the right or left of the political spectrum; a particular party may win a large number of seats for various historical or cultural reasons, e.g., due to a large presence in some areas of Britain outside of Britain itself, or an unpopular leader whose party lost an important election a few years ago but still commands some support. This is how the House of Commons works, and has worked for hundreds of years, in Britain. The United States works in somewhat the same way, although with some important differences.

Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Concept of a “Population Tree”: Revisited", published in Conservation Biology. In it they argue that there is a great deal of confusion about how to conceptualize the concept of a phylogenetic tree.

They first note that the most common human population tree that researchers build consists of a linear list of populations with an implied common ancestor. They then go on to note the problem with what they call the “tree of a tree” problem -- that the concept of a linear population tree requires a nested population tree (this latter population tree itself being based on a nested population tree).

The authors argue that all population trees with a common ancestor are just as valid as other population trees (as opposed to a phylogenetic tree), and that the problem with nested population trees is that a nested population tree is simply a different sort

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go far beyond duty and its traditional limitations, namely, "the limits of humanity" in general. There are no limits to what a person can become, since the human in general is limitless or unbounded. (Hegel, _Vorlesungen_ ( _Werke_ ), 7:14–16)

Israelites enjoyed political independence twice in ancient history, first during the periods of the Biblical judges followed by the United Monarchy.[disputed – discuss] This form of government lasted approximately 500 years, between the reigns of Judges and Saul the 1st king.[disputed – discuss] During this time, Israel was a monarchy. Then the monarchy was replaced by a two-tiered political system, a theocratic state with king and priests. In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, the city was restituted to France in accordance with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson’s commitment to the League of Nations. In 1926, on the initiative of the Vichy government, the French League of Nations awarded the city to Germany. As an international border city, Rheims had a mixed population of nearly 900,000 people of French nationality, 600,000 French soldiers, 200,000 Germans, and 30,000 Belgians. Although most of the city’s pre-1914 buildings survived largely undamaged or barely so in the German army’s shelling during World War II (during which some 25,000 people were killed and 300,000 were made homeless), Rheims’ destruction during the final months of the war was unprecedented. The Germans systematically destroyed the majority of the city’s buildings, including churches and public statues, and removed many of its historic monuments.

During the early years, MCA also manufactured discs for other companies including Paramount, Disney and Warner Bros. Some of them added their own names to the back cover. The first album released in this format was "The Sound of Summer" by the Hollywood Stars in 1966.

It turns out that over half of the Neolithic farmers lived, worked and buried in this small region in that period of human prehistory.

Archaeologists have dubbed this region Skhoybey in honor of the Bulgarian village and its nearby church. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that the knowing subject could not have failed to know it. Popper wanted to preserve the former while rejecting the latter. In "The New Frontier of Quasi-Realism and of Logical Positivism", Popper (1964/1993) put it thus: I believe that it is necessary to make two distinctions. The distinction between the subject knowing something which is true, and the subject knowing something on which he or she depends for deciding what to do. (Popper 1964/1993: 8-9) Knowledge, for Popper, was objective because the knowing subject did not have to make the judgement that he knew. Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for the United States and elsewhere. For example, no legislation of any kind was ever passed by parliament, but only by orders in council, granted directly by the king, who thereby exercised absolute authority in all matters. Thus, in a matter of practical importance, Parliament was merely the debating body, not the law-making body, and this was not even the whole story. The king's prerogative of mercy, exercised in the exercise of a royal prerogative, could, in some special cases, exempt from execution those convicted of lesser crimes than capital offenses.[10]

Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served to maintain and disseminate the religious doctrines. A madras or madrasa, literally "place of knowledge," is a school or a college or a higher seminary. Although there is evidence for madrasas in different times and locations (and hence madrasas with different names, depending on location),  the Ottoman madrisat movement was specifically inspired by the madrasa at Al-Azhar University in Cairo, Egypt. The Ottoman state attempted to emulate and implement this model of education from Cairo in order to establish a large and well-educated bureaucracy, as well as an educated military force, since the elite officer corps was particularly weak in the military-ruled Ottoman state. Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to acquire lands by force, however, as the feudal rights of certain noble families made them less amenable to royal command.

In 1329, a particularly contentious king, Philip VI, issued a demand for the hand of Jeanne de la Baume, duchess of Anjou, in marriage to claim a hereditary baronage. In his attempts to marry her off, he had failed to secure a feudal grant of her lands, and he decided to take the duke of Anjou out of play by using the royal power of taxation. He thus instituted a tithe (one quarter of all money, and taxes on various sorts of goods), which was to be paid annually throughout the duchy of Anjou and its dependencies. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea began to break up. The earliest known Jurassic fossils of an oviraptorid dinosaur and theropod dinosaur Sinosauropteryx were found in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of China. The first known oviraptorid fossils are approximately 155 million years old, and the first dinosaurs with feathers appear in the fossil record at approximately 125Ma.

Early life and discovery, as well as the characteristics of the fossils and some of their most interesting discoveries, are discussed. Early Jurassic fossil discoveries, including the first and second oviraptorid specimens, which were discovered in the Lushiha site, in the Shishudun Formation in the Uyghur Autonomous Region of China are detailed.

The sultan of the Ottoman Empire was also called the “Caliph” while at home and abroad. The caliphate continued until the proclamation of the Republic of Turkey in 1923, when the Ottoman dynasty was abolished. The Ottoman Sultan Abdülmecid II declared the sultan Abdülaziz, his son, as the first head of the new, independent state of Turkey in 1876.

In 1718, at the behest of either Rector Samuel Andrew or the colony's Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather contacted a few friends about his findings about the apparition. The friends were Benjamin West, John Smibert and Nathaniel Cutting. These three individuals are considered foremost to have documented the case.

The first two members of the core group of researchers were members of his church and the church's minister. The congregation was known to be quite sensitive to phenomena. West had his own studio where he made reproductions of paintings and would later have a career as a major painter in the New England area. Smibert was a famous painter. Smibert's wife was a distant neighbor of Mather's wife. The two are known to have formed a strong personal relationship while Mather was a minister in the First Church.

Cutting was a minister at the South Cove church. He had just retired after 22 years of religious service there.

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, who formed the first Celtic culture around Galicia (or Galatia in Greek) in the 6th century BC. The Roman name of the area, Hispania, was derived from the name of the Gallaeci and it was in the 2nd and 1st centuries BC that they were conquered by the Celtiberians and their kingdom was broken up into four independent kingdoms in what is sometimes called a "pre-Roman" period of history.

Gallaecia, as a territory, was organized into three districts by Pompey against the Suebi. To the north, the Suebi had their capital at Lugdunum (today's capital of Lyon in France), and to the west and south of that, at Emerita Augusta (today's Rodez in France).

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. Their extremely large lungs and thin blood with a high haemoglobin concentration, as compared to mammals, allow the concentration of oxygen in the blood to reach very high levels. Their blood is less viscous and it circulates more rapidly.

The avian liver is highly adapted to produce glucose. In a study in the 1970s that measured blood glucose in birds, it was found to be over 50 mmol/L, more than double than human levels. It is proposed that the liver can maintain this high level because it may be able to convert glycogen directly into glucose, and that the liver, therefore, is more important in glucose utilization for metabolism, rather than for storage as in mammals.

As anticipated by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived off Midway on 4 June and was spotted by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo executed a first-of-class battle order maneuver, in which the carriers proceeded directly across the path of the Midway invasion force and launched attack planes. During this maneuver, Nagumo's scout carriers _Akagi, Soryu, Kurita_, and _Atago_ became separated from the carriers. His flagship, the carrier _Akagi_, continued directly toward Midway but became the first Japanese ship to be hit by a dive-bomber, striking without warning and forcing Nagumo to break off battle formation. Admiral Yamamoto's flagship, the battleship _Yamato_, and the four light carriers _Shokaku, Zuikaku, Hiryu_, and _Junyo_ headed back to base for repair, leaving Midway unopposed.

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents become aware of the social and physical distinctions that separate them from other groups. They are also likely to explore their roles in school, work, family and peers, and they may try out various identities and interests (Elliott & Daugherty, 1997; Eisenberg, & Spinrad, 1980; Steinberg, 1999). During this stage, identity confusion, which may be caused by the adolescent's lack of control over his or her development, or by others' reactions to the changing behaviors and aspirations of the adolescent (e.g., parents, friends), often causes some confusion. However, the adolescent who avoids confusion and avoids negative reactions from others often avoids the problems and stresses that can come with identity confusion. The present chapter provides information about identity development during the adolescent years.

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of egocentrism (a desire to have others' views valued and to avoid social rejection), egocentrism is a characteristic of high school students (e.g., Baer et al., [@B2]; Kim et al., [@B18]).

Egocentrism is considered an important factor contributing to suicide behaviors and ideation (Kessler et al., [@B17]; Dohrenwend et al., [@B8]). Social rejection by others has been identified as an important precipitating factor in suicidal ideation and behavior (e.g., Kessler et al., [@B16]). Thus, understanding the features of adolescent egocentrism can lead to more accurate identification of individuals at high risk of suicidal ideation and suicidal behaviors. Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine after a meal to raise blood pressure levels.

After years of research, in which he performed several trials, Schachter concluded that raising blood pressure is more important than lowering cholesterol for lowering total mortality.

He also stated that even if lowering cholesterol is important — Schachter felt the evidence wasn't strong enough to justify the statin drugs — that reducing cholesterol has to start with dietary measures, and that there was insufficient evidence to say that lowering cholesterol through the use of statins lowers atherosclerosis.

This theory was accepted early in the 21st Century and became the standard of care — until 2012, when new cholesterol-lowering statins were introduced.

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus' continued dominance was ensured by an agreement between the Qing government and the Dzungar leader Galdan Boshugtu Khan. Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these migrations resulted in at least two founders who survived well beyond 300 CE, which can be demonstrated from the Y-chromosome and their autosomal lineages (see later).

This is not a new idea, but new evidence that was collected prior to 2005 is now being published. Most new data about Jewish and Muslim Arab populations is based upon Y-chromosome DNA, and was not previously available for many populations.

Y-chromosome studies have provided the first proof that the Arabs from the Arabian peninsula and the Near East are the descendants of the Israelite patriarchs who fled to Egypt, and who later returned to their homeland from Egypt. This was previously thought to be a myth. The new data is supported by genetic studies that were also just published, with the findings having the same time frame.

The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented.

All of us are born with a limited exposure to the antigens in our environment, such as food. Exposure happens when a baby sucks a nipple, sucks her tongue into the mouth, or sucks her fingers into her mouth. Antigen presentation occurs through the mother's milk. These are called gut antigens. These antigens present themselves to the babies by presenting on the cells in the mother's milk. They are also present in breastmilk when taken orally.

There are also antigens on skin and mucous membranes where the body's protective barriers are thin. These are called environmental antigens.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as urates. There appear to be very few bird species that drink; the few that do, drink only saline water.

Unlike reptiles, however, birds can make urine more concentrated by having more reabsorptive nephrons to conserve salt. Birds have a highly developed renal medulla, and the uricosuric response occurs only when the bird is dehydrated. The renal response is a complex, hormonal response mediated by the renin-aldosterone system. Renin is released by the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus in response to reduced circulating concentrations of blood volume, and aldosterone is released by the adrenal cortex in response to the higher concentration of angiotensin II that results as the renin releases angiotensinogen. Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, privilege and protection unavailable to secular clerics.

‘No man, however, might ever become a pope unless he was elected by the Holy Roman Church and ordained by the Roman Pontiff,’ writes John Paul II in Veritatis Splendor. ‘As a consequence, while there were many bishops and priests who held the office of pope, there was but a single pope and “Bishop of Rome”.’

The Roman papacy was the seat of the Church after the Apostolic See, and had special primacy over the churches of other nations as well as over the universal order of bishops and priests, from which the bishops of the rest of the world ultimately derived their authority.

The popes were the heads of the universal Church, and their primacy was exercised by virtue of their office.

The NES would be the first game system that Nintendo sold exclusively in North America.

One of the differences would become a key feature of the system's early life; the system was programmed with a game-pushing hardware system, called the Zorro co-processor. The Danaoi, however, are defined in more detail, as the sons of the Greek Danaus. A few details have survived about the name. Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values. In addition to the dollar the coinage act also authorized a dollar unit, in the form of the cent, to be issued, and in fact was issued for less than a year and a half before being discontinued, although its status as a legal tender was to endure until 1857. That is, however, too early in the history of the U.S. for it to have served as a standard for the entire country, as European countries and their colonies had a currency system in which each country or area had its own currency based upon the coinage of that area. In its initial stages many U.S. states used the dollar unit as part of their currency but these eventually replaced it. The British adopted the dollar while the colony of Canada adopted a similar cent. The French adopted the dollar unit as well. For years, the U.S. dollar was the world's foremost currency

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the contest between two or more wrestlers consists of multiple "rungs" of a ladder (i.e. five ladders for the five-star match) in ascending order, each match between one member of one promotion and one member of another promotion being a different and independent ladder match. If a wrestler manages to reach the top of his or her division's ladder at the time of a scheduled match, that wrestler won the match by default; however, that wrestler is able to force the match by either hitting the corner ropes—in which case whoever remained on the apron is eliminated, or by climbing down (most but not all ladder matches stipulate that wrestlers must climb down) the ladder to win.

Other match setups of ladder matches include stipulating certain moves to be performed in specific positions, or adding an entire piece of ladders

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, a true predator does not kill its prey simply by being bigger or more violent; a killer relies on cunning. Unlike its prey a true predator may not be very effective in killing its prey. For that reason it is a rare type of predator in the real world that kills animals like humans and other mammals of its size. A true predator is also rarely seen in their natural habitat today—only in nature's densest wildlife preservation areas and on predator-free islands. Predatory species tend to be smaller in the natural habitat in their natural areas. In the wild, the predator must rely on its surroundings in order to meet and acquire its prey. They do not have to get in a hunter-gatherer chase where they risk injury and death attempting to track, ambush, and hunt down prey.

All present and former heads of state of the Commonwealth may attend the Coronation.

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles.

We can also visualize the electron as a point particle and, knowing the values of its spin at any point in space, deduce its behavior over time.

In the end, the electron is a theory of a particle that has a tiny spin associated with it – just like Feynman would have calculated the force exerted between the electrons in his diagram – and thus has all the properties of the electron: energy, mass, charge, etc.

In general, all of physics is about solving these types of problems. If they all could be reduced to a problem of particles meeting one another head-on, we would know everything there is to know about matter.

Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism, the power of political machines, or the “skeletons in the closet,” to name a few. This semester, I decided to test the power of these explanations, focusing on Yale student efforts on campus during spring 1973. My study found that Yale student voters had little motivation to act based on campus politics. This finding counters earlier, and much less scholarly, claims about the influence of Yale student politics on national elections.

One explanation for Yale’s involvement in national elections is political machines. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to be an academic child-welfare agency: it could provide the research, information, and service necessary to help social agencies work with families. One of the first child-welfare agencies in the country, it became a model of collaboration between a research institute, concerned with identifying and remedying children's problems, and a child-welfare agency, concerned primarily with helping families.

The Institute's success has led some to ask whether child welfare programs as a whole could learn from its innovative use of scientific evaluation research. The answer is yes and no, depending on the particular program that is under consideration. As Macfarlane noted in a 1990 publication, "The Institute model is not the same for all programs, and the programs must decide how to define and implement the principles which form its core."

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez and Orlando Lassus. 

Early examples of the use of polyphony in Christian music include the Vigilius, a polyphonic setting of the Requiem Mass, written by Josquin des Prez, who in turn was working from the melodies of Orlandus Lassus. This song, which Josquin's father Guillaume, an organist and choirmaster, had first written for Orlandus, was first performed at the funeral of Isabella of France in Lyon in 1469. The melody of Gervase de Tilbury's Missa sine nomine, written around 1492, is said to originate from an earlier a cappella setting titled Missa pro defunctis, although the actual origin of this piece is unknown.

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe lay in ruins, and its population was decimated. Britain, for its part, lost over 600,000 dead and nearly 2 million injured, and the country’s economy was shattered. Germany and Japan were also heavily damaged.

As the Allies looked to rebuild their post-war worlds, it was important to maintain the infrastructure which allowed them to defeat the Nazis and Japanese. But, at the same time, they were anxious to avoid repeating the past mistakes which led to them falling into such a destructive conflict in the first place. Both sides were keen to move away from the nationalism and aggression which had fueled the Second World War, and work hard to develop new post-war international relations based on cooperation and the sharing of resources.

The impact upon the city could only be exaggerated when, 10 days later, the Glasgow Corporation made the first proposal of its kind: in a matter of weeks, it was to transfer its operations to East, Central London. By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war with France, a series of conflicts with the United States flared up on the frontier in what is called the “War of 1812.”

One of these conflicts started at a place called Lake Erie and led to a major invasion of Canadian territory by an army of the United States and an amphibious landing at a place called Plattsburgh. It was a decisive American victory, and a direct precursor to the major U.S. invasion of Mexico less than a decade later.

Yet the United States did not invade Canada until a war with Mexico in a later decade, so these two conflicts were the first major war against Canada in U.S. history.

The U.S. invasion of Canada would happen during the War of 1812, a war that would later lead to the formation of the United States of America

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic. For example, even if the memory trace is not actively preserved, it can be amplified when the associated experiences repeat, a phenomenon known as sensitization.

Because the hippocampus is a major memory center for both short and long-term memories, the molecular mechanisms underlying its formation and maintenance have been intensively studied and extensively described (e.g., [@bib27]). The study of these mechanisms has been greatly improved by the use of new research tools such as transgenic mice. As described below, many exciting findings have been made; however, a major hurdle is the complexity of memory. Most processes in the brain occur in several places and work jointly. When trying to understand such complex functions, it may be a challenge for us to consider the interactions between the involved processes. How do all these things work together in the memory process?

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., anger, aggression, disgust, and sadness), self-categorization (e.g., identification with society and the individual), individual emotions (e.g., fear, envy, and shame), or emotion systems (e.g., defense/withdrawal, attack, and threat) that determine the level of activation of one or more subsystems. The conceptual distinction between emotion and affect is based on the distinction between basic versus secondary processes in cognition and on the distinction between emotional and affective (e.g., hedonic, conative, cognitive-motivational) responses ([@B3]). Emotions are conceptualized as being core, cognitive, and motivational, whereas cognitions and motivation, though core and cognitive, are secondary and nonemotional.

An example of this is William of Ockham (1286-1347), one of the most important nominalist philosophers; the other example is Albertus Magnus (1193-1280), a physician, philosopher, and theologian.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend bylaws. A board-only organization consists only of the board, but it's the board that makes decisions.

The board is made up of elected people that come from either the membership or the community at large. Once a new president and CEO is named, the board discusses possible candidates. The board then narrows down the selection and asks people in the community to vote.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy and blasphemy—the accused Christian’s parents are notified. If they refuse to submit to the elders of their local church, the case may go straight to the elders of the church body as a whole. The congregation is thus permitted to consider the matter in public session and to judge the person’s guilt. If they condemn him, then a church member called “a pastor” (from the Greek word pisteuo, to “condemn,”) is appointed to give a verbal “counsel” (Greek advitos, counsel). The pastor can also use his Bible at the time to justify his condemnation of the guilty party. Such action does not need to be ratified by a second church body. The person’s family is then allowed to “absolve” him

Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the first menstrual period a girl has and becomes sexually active) and male puberty (the physical and hormonal changes a boy experiences during puberty) are milestones that signal the end of childhood sexual development and the start of full physical and sexual maturity. Yet, it seems that many cultures do not place an immediate sexual and reproductive responsibility on youth. Many adolescents begin having sex soon after the transition into sexual adulthood, and sometimes continue to have sex into early adulthood. The consequences of late sexual initiation include a higher likelihood of teen pregnancy, other reproductive and sexual health problems, and a higher likelihood of infection with an HIV-1, HIV-2, or other sexually transmitted infection. In addition, the physical and psychological impacts of unwanted or unplanned pregnancy often affect a young woman and her family far into adulthood.

As part of the University's 50th anniversary celebrations in 1926, the editors published a collection of historical essays about the paper over the previous 100 years, titled "The Daily Northwestern: A Collection of Its Works".

The University's Office of Undergraduate Education has established several student magazines and yearbooks aimed at students, including the College News-Crimson, Honors, and Campus Times.

Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia was one of the European participants in the “Association of Baltic States,” formed in 2008 after the fall of the Soviet Union. In 2009, Estonia became the first former Soviet republic to join NATO, and in 2012 it joined the European Union, the world’s largest single market. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions," and sometimes were as such, the term "invasion" does not adequately describe the reality of what actually took place. In fact, the term most often used is "invasion," but even this is not the full story, as I will also be pointing out various kinds of movements at work.

These movements were the outcome of the interaction of the Roman Empire with the peoples around it during the centuries following the decline of the Western Empire. In the past, this interaction was relatively small -- the area between Italy and the Rhine was the area the most affected, and to an extent the Western and central Germanic provinces, but to say that "all of western and central Europe was affected is incorrect, because such an assertion does not take into account the specificities of each province." Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of the pack.

The study, involving 400 students in eight regional Gymnasiums, found that almost half the students had mathematical abilities in the bottom half, while just over a fifth got into the top half of the academic performance.

The findings, carried out by Prof. Dr. Werner Neubauer of Johannes-Gutenberg University in Mainz, a member of the German Mathematical Society, provide an insight into why Germany is set to miss out on this year’s maths Olympiad when its team will have just three members.

“We asked them how well they can do mathematical questions, like sums, multiplication, etc.,” said Prof. Neubauer, who was asked to assess the mathematical performance of the German Mathematical Olympiad selection at the school level.

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (primarily Italy and other non-German and francophone countries) parts of Europe developed along largely parallel lines within a similar historical context. The influence of the Roman Catholic Church on society (especially in Latin Europe), the centrality of the Germanic church, and an overall climate of conformity often characterised the period, and these factors also influenced the types of institutions developed. In the south, the papacy exercised relatively more political influence at the courts of the nobility over the Church (the Emperor being the ultimate political authority). The Church, by contrast, was far less politically influential in the north, although it did continue to exert power over universities in Germany, and as the German states became sovereign states the universities gained considerable independence. Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A sample suspected of containing microbial organism is added to the growth medium in an attempt to induce bacterial, fungal or other similar microorganism growth. The agent is isolated by adding antimicrobial agents to the growth medium to inhibit such growth.
The present invention is adapted to analyze specimens suspected of being infected with fungi. More particularly, the invention pertains to a method for detecting or diagnosing infection of tissue cells or body fluids with a fungus. The invention thus detects the presence of the mycelium or any hyphae within the suspected tissue specimen. Mycelium of fungi, according to the invention, is defined as the hyphal phase of fungi propagating on the surface of a substrate and is distinguishable from fungal spores. While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many local traditions, customs, parading, and festive events were connected to the pre-Tridentine religious feasts of St. John, Corpus Christi, and All Saints Day.

Sights and events in the city of York

The site of York has changed over the years, but in 1066, the Domesday Book recorded that the city had 6,000 inhabitants, a large majority of whom were freemen. York was also the birthplace of the poet, and the first English monarch, King Edgar, in 973. The city flourished with the Viking invasions in the Anglo-Saxon period, and in the early Middle Ages with ecclesiastic and mercantile trade. York, in its present form, originated with the Norman Conquest of 1068.

Education in Israel is highly valued in the national culture with its historical values dating back to Ancient Israel and was viewed as one fundamental blocks of ancient Israelite wisdom. Education at all levels was provided for the community. For example, the biblical Book Deuteronomy is known to contain the first recorded use of what is generally referred to as "Hebrew University." The term is derived from the fact that it contained the oldest college at the time in the Kingdom of Judah. Prior to the Hebrew University a school was established in Jerusalem.

After the fall of ancient Israel, Jewish learning continued to flourish, especially in Roman Palestine. While the Jews maintained a strong and rich culture following the Roman decline, the Jews entered the Byzantine Empire (which was based in Jerusalem), and their cultural influence within this area intensified.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence over the course of social events, and their influence may not be acknowledged until they are able to exert considerable control over others. In this study we examine whether parents who are supportive of their child's adolescent behaviors and emotions (i.e., parents with a "warm" rather than a "cold" parental style) use more "warm" (i.e., supportive) parenting practices and less over-control. Specifically, adolescents' age, and levels of emotional expressiveness were found to predict both higher levels of parental warmth/supportiveness and lower levels of over-control. However, both parents' warmth/supportiveness predicted lower degrees of over-control. Finally, adolescents who were more expressive during a discussion with their mother were more likely to be perceived, by the other parent, as being in an adolescent's role rather than as a child

The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi announced in an interview that his country's budget deficit would not exceed $2.5 billion by 1990. The public sector was expanded, while income tax, sales tax and other indirect taxes were significantly increased for both individuals and companies.

As the economy became more diversified and foreign investment began to flow into the country, private companies became important to Libya's economic development. As of 2013, 70 percent of economic activity was still state-controlled.

In the early 1990s, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Libya experienced a decline in oil revenues due in part to the drop in oil prices, especially following the Gulf War. Geographical position
The district is situated in the central plains of Madhya Pradesh. The district borders the districts of Bhopal and Jabalpur to the south, Ratlam to the east, Shahdol to the northeast, Barwaha and Hoshangabad to the north, and Khargone and Shivpuri to the west. The Ravi River runs through the western part of the district. The Gomti River flows through the southern part.

The first Marshall Field store was organized as a partnership which, however, operated in a highly competitive manner and the field soon became a corporate entity. In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689, 2nd ed. 1690) that the rational part of our mind is capable of gaining knowledge about the world by means of introspection—by self-observation—which is based on understanding. In his Essay on Human Understanding, Locke uses the parable of Thomas and Peter to illustrate his view that the human mind has introspective capacities inasmuch as it can know the content of its own ideas. He also offers a more systematic account of this capacity in the "Essay" to help him show that we only have mental knowledge of particular ideas.

Before forming Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor had played together in a band named Smile. Freddie Mercury (then known by his birth name of Farrokh Bulsara) and the band eventually became Queen. After performing at parties and festivals around the UK, the band played their first full-fledged gig in 1974 at the Marquee Club in London. A few months later, the band went on to write and record their first album, Queen, which was released that year.

Mercury left the band in 1975 to join a Japanese band and was replaced by drummer/composer John Deacon. After recording a number of singles that did not receive much of a response, the band reunited in 1977 and released A Day at the Races, the album that established them as a true music group with original songs and a polished stage act. Freddie Mercury died of complications from AIDS in 1991. He was gay. He is widely regarded as the defining musical talent of the post-punk era.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessalic Peninsula, Ancient Macedon, Central Greece and Western Macedonia, today in Greece. The term is also used by Homer's Greek contemporaries for Greeks generally.

The language of the Ionians in antiquity was not Greek, but a mixture of the Thracian and the Aeolian dialects, which had different levels of Hellenic influence. The Greek language developed from proto-Ionic from c. 725 bc, as the dialect of most Ionian-speaking Greeks in the west, and, under the influence of other Aeolian-speaking populations from other areas who had settled in the same region, from 725 to 480 began to take over most of the Ionian-speaking mainland Greeks (notably Athens). Initially, the Turkish Cypriots favoured the continuation of the British rule. However, they were alarmed by the Greek Cypriot calls for enosis, and their calls for an end to the Treaty of Guarantee. The Cypriot problem became part and parcel of Turkish public discourse at the level of political rhetoric, because of the large Turkish diaspora. Turkish public opinion favoured enosis at the time, as a means of "integrating" Cyprus with Turkey.

Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert its authority over the other kingdoms of France. Under the first four Bourbons the French monarchy would continue to expand its authority over the other states of France, eventually bringing all of them under the authority of the monarch.

During the French Revolution the nobility were given the right to vote and the monarchy eliminated, with the nobility still not having power by 1793. After the end of the monarchy, power came under the control of the state. The Directory was a period where power remained with the state, but was unstable due to the war and the conflict between Napoleon Bonaparte and his enemies within France.

Seattle typically receives some snowfall on an annual basis but heavy snow is rare. Average annual snowfall, as measured at Sea-Tac Airport, has varied from a low of 21.4 centimeters (8.8 inches) to a high of 27.1 centimeters (10.8 inches) from January 1950 through December 2010 (National Weather Service). According to the December 2006 Northwest Snow Survey, Seattle received about 5.23 inches of snow from November 2005 through December 2006, the average for the same period being 4.76 inches. Although a severe flood occurred in downtown Seattle in November 2005, Seattle has not experienced a major flood since then nor a significant ice storm in a decade.

The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), with the goal of building the first spacecraft capable of carrying a human being into Earth orbit, and subsequently becoming the first to land on another celestial body. After President Eisenhower's speech at the United Nations during the opening of the 1958–59 session, a decision was made to conduct a test flight of the rocket-powered spacecraft Vanguard 1 in the course's second orbital flight, which had been planned for the previous July. The test flight occurred on October 5, 1958, during which the rocket was first placed in orbit, and then destroyed to prevent other nations from learning about its capabilities. On release, Twilight Princess was considered to be the greatest Zelda game ever made by many critics including writers for 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, GameSpot, GameSpy, Nintendo Life, IGN, Official Nintendo Magazine and Game Revolution, who gave it all four of their top awards. Although these articles typically do not assign an official rating, Twilight Princess's reviews were generally much more enthusiastic than those of other Zelda games released during the same period.

Twilight Princess was released for GameCube as well as for the Wii's Virtual Console in North America and Europe on October 25, 2006. It was later made available for download on the 3DS's Virtual Console on January 23, 2013. In 2018, Twilight Princess received remakes for modern consoles, with a 3D port developed by Nintendo's Advanced Nintendo 3DS Development team for Nintendo 3DS, and a remade version for Wii U and Nintendo Switch released on June 28, 2018 and September 20, 2018, respectively.

After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, seized control of Pergamum and Rhodes, and installed his son Cassander II as king. Since he was a very young king, however, he appointed a regent, his sister Apama, who, while her husband Philip was young and inexperienced, acted on his behalf. This began an uneasy marriage alliance between Macedonia and Philip's Ptolemaic and Seleucid enemies.

The years from 288 till 280 BCE were the golden years of Macedonia. Philip not only reorganized the state into four official provinces but also reorganized its military. Established bands made something of a comeback in the mid-1980s. After an 8-year separation, Deep Purple returned with the classic Machine Head album. Black Sabbath made a comeback, followed soon after by Judas Priest. The latter, however, proved to be short-lived. With the exception of Metallica, who began a career-long streak of commercial and critical success, all of these bands have fallen back to relative obscurity (except Metallica, which has since reached iconic status).

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office. The trial has been in a court of public opinion in the press and on the pages of The Sun newspaper itself and in the world of media outlets and bloggers.

The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features: The Army of Italy's task was "very great, almost too great for us." There is a "suddenness, a speed, and a movement" that need to be maintained: "I would lose nothing by all the speed for which my troops are trained, their energy and their courage." There were also particular challenges: "to avoid the enemy corps d'armee, which might be sent to join M. de Macdonald." There were also important opportunities: "not one more day lost, but every day counts, and there is very little time to lose." One final detail was significant: "The artillery has been in mass here for some time. Nothing must be allowed to take up its time."

In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, a virtuoso pianist with whom he had formed a close friendship in London. The festival was intended to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the birth of a great musician and to be conducted by the celebrated German musician and music critic Eduard Hanslick. The festival had been planned to be a two-week affair, but on May 9 it was called off after a cholera epidemic broke out and many of the concert goers died. Chopin's impressions are recorded in a letter to Hiller.

With respect to these outer regions, the Qing maintained imperial control, with the emperor acting as Mongol khan, patron of Tibetan Buddhism and protector of Muslims, Mongolian tribes, Tibetan soldiers, and Han bannermen. Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a strong personality, which does not accept “outsiders” being part of the social group he/she belongs to. An example of this is the strong leader of a political group, who will not accept any other political leader who disagrees even slightly.

On the other hand, an inclusive boundary implies that a person is open for other ideas, but not necessarily accepting all ideas he/she does not agree with. This is the case, for example, with a scientist who is open for discussions, but who is extremely protective of the way he/she thinks, including any alternative view within his/her scientific method.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species were ecologically successful and thus became the dominant group of ungulates. However, most living mammals are herbivores, some of them quite successfully and are therefore still widely distributed in the animal kingdom. Others still exist in a semi-domesticated state due to their small size or because of their limited dietary habits, and are therefore of great interest to conservationists.

The earliest species probably consisted of a few mammals that looked like their modern descendants but were much smaller. Many of these early mammals were the first to come into contact with fire. This gave them the opportunity to cook their food, something that was a great ecological advantage early in the mammalian fossil record. The earliest true mammals probably appeared around 50 millions years ago, soon after the world’s landmasses had emerged from the oceans.

The lawsuit claimed that women are not held to the exact same GPA requirements as men and that the law school required females to take more pre-law education courses than males. To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is often quite difficult in the case of large, multi-station high-speed systems. Such multi-station high-speed systems typically require a high number of feeder stations to be maintained as isolated, high speed sections to meet the customer delivery requirements. Accordingly, systems are needed that overcome such limitations.
The present invention relates a system designed to effectively isolate phase portions of a feeder station, while keeping them in phase with the system's main supply frequency. In one embodiment, the present invention maintains phase portions in a constant phase relationship with the main supply frequency. A separate auxiliary power source drives the phase portions of the feeder system so that the two portions of the system can freely drift apart without phase confusion with the main supply frequency. In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the café society began to grow, and cafés (usually located near the Seine river, which runs through the city) became very popular. Cafes became chic places, popular with writers, artists and the aristocracy, but also with people of the middle class. The best cafés today are located in the 5th and 6th arrondissements of Paris. The traditional brasserie and the baron café have spread throughout the country. The old drinking fountains had little tables nearby and were frequented by workers during the working day. The more elaborate cafés and bistros have become restaurants. Today, there are so many French cafés with good food that a typical student doesn't have to eat out more than once a week. A student today rarely sees a cafe without a bar.
