It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began. The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (formerly Rensselaer Union) trace their roots to 1906. The New England University Chorus (now New England University A Cappella) was formed four years later. In 1916, the University of Michigan, led by music educator Ralph Claus, began a cappella performance as an extracurricular club, with the hope that it would one day become a separate co-curricular organization. University of Michigan alumna Beth Blonder has conducted the UM Singers since the early 1930s, making it the oldest active collegiate a cappella group in the United States today.

The National Association of Collegiate Directors of Art (NACDA) defines collegiate artistic a cappella as "an on-campus group of singers whose function as an a cappella group is to perform artistic arrangements of music on a regular basis."

Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and burn their beard. The edict further required that women shave their head hair at the front, and allow men to shave their pubic hair as well.[2] The edict also stated that women with unshaven heads may be arrested during the night and fined up to 30% of their annual revenue,[2] but this clause was rescinded after two months.[1] The edict may not have been followed rigorously. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. As fatty acids are essential for a wide variety of biological functions, the body has many biochemical pathways to regulate their production and catabolism, and thus maintain their homeostasis. Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections caused by certain microorganisms were known as antimicrobials. Antimicrobials were used with some success to treat infections of plants and animals. This was the origin of the word "antibiotic" (from *anti*, against, and *biotic*).[@b1]

As a result of the application of antimicrobials in humans, veterinary medicine and agriculture, the term "antibiotic" has spread to a wide range of agents that are widely believed to have therapeutic activity against a wide range of microorganisms with specific resistance.[@b2] Many drugs are classified as antimicrobial and used empirically for the treatment of infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria, Gram-negative bacteria, protozoa, and fungi. However, not all antibiotics have the same mechanism of action.

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped until the end of the half without restarting at 5 minutes before half time or the final whistle. A standard game also has ten added time periods throughout the first half known as added on time, totalling a one-and-a–half time period that is added onto time already expired. Add on time can be called by either the offence or the defence, and after four added on time it is then "dead time". The first half of a game is known as "firsts", as that is the period when teams have the last chance to score before the start of the second half.

Each half is divided into three parts, and the first half ends when the clock reads 15:00 (fifteen minutes of play), followed by stoppage by the referee, as opposed to going to a point that is usually scored at 15

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to interact with others, to learn from new friends, and to develop more effective social skills.

By learning how to communicate with or in peer groups, adolescents are better able to achieve positive peer relationships in later years.

Communication within peer groups affects the extent to which adolescents' peer identities are formed and reinforced.

Communication within peer groups affects the extent to which adolescents' feelings about themselves are regulated--their emotions and their relationships to others.

Communication within peer groups may even impact the extent of adolescents' involvement with the school, their participation in extracurricular activities, and the extent to which they get high marks in school.

This chapter outlines the importance and value of peer socialization--and why it is necessary for adolescents to develop and practice skills that promote their peer relationships.

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the colony’s relatively short history – a mere 40 years – Penn and his successors would be called “fathers” of Pennsylvania due to their extensive land holdings in central and eastern Pennsylvania, and the role the colony would play in the American Revolution.

Penn’s original grant consisted of vast tracts of land stretching from the Delaware River at Wilmington to the Chesapeake Bay at the Maryland state line. Today, the colony is divided into four counties: Bucks, Chester, Lancaster, and Philadelphia. The county in which most of Penn’s land is located is Philadelphia County, in which Penn’s estate is located.

Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the same region of northwest Europe from the fifth to the seventh century and each group, according to the British Museum and the Cambridge History of Ireland, was conquered by the Roman Empire.

Although they originated from different language groups (see below), the five Insular Celtic tribes are in general comparable in culture and civilization. Histo-grams indicate that they were closely related and the same general ethnic grouping had been present in northwest Europe for hundreds of years prior to the Roman invasion.

Celtic culture in Ireland developed in response to the agricultural economy and new technologies brought by the Roman conquest. Celtic culture spread from the Irish Sea to Europe, but by the late period, its influence had declined.

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the hippocampus are formed and reactivated to form long-term memories. If, after learning, the person sleeps without interruption, the memory is consolidated, making the memory permanently available for later recall (McCormack et al., [@B45]; Gass and Benson, [@B19]). The ability to consolidate memory is dependent on sleep and on the brain structures and chemical messengers needed for memory transmission (McGaugh et al., [@B43]). The neural pathways from the hippocampus must be reactivated for it to transfer new information to long-term memory. The hippocampus produces and sends out a chemical message called N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor binding glutamate to an area of the brain called the frontal cortex. The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the Syrian provinces formed the core of the empire. Greek was the language of the empire and was spoken by about half the population; Aramaic and Persian were also commonly used. The province was an economically, culturally and politically dependent territory, though to what degree was not fully known. The Seleucids ruled the territory from the Hellenistic city of Seleucia Pieria, near Antioch.

As part of the Seleucid Empire, Syria saw some of the most significant reforms of Greek institutions. After Diogenes of Babylon in the 3rd century BC, the Seleucids promoted Greek culture across the empire, and made Antioch into a major center of Hellenism. They also encouraged the growth of cities and improved trade. They established a system of tax collection from their subjects, and a postal department. The Se

Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not simply for the sake of horses, but were also for diplomatic reasons. Indeed, they argue that the Ming had an imperial ideology called the “Five Religions”. The Ming saw Tibet, and the Gelugs in particular, as the representative for the world, an ideology that was also reflected in the Gelugs’ own practices. In Tibet at this time, the Gelugs did not accept Buddhist or Daoist influences, and it is very likely that the Ming hoped to have their imperial ideology, namely Confucianism, recognized in Tibet, an attitude that they would have had less of if the Dalai Lama, and the Gelugpa in particular, had refused their request for horses. The first railways in Thuringia had been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines had been built in the east and south, while in the west a single line led to Bad Frankenhausen. In the Thuringian Forest, the Harz Railway Company (Gesellschaft zur Verwahrung der Eisenbahnen Thüringen a. o.) began building the first branch line of East Thuringia, from Buna to Jena, in the autumn of 1879. This line was completed in 1883.

The railway history of East Thuringia runs parallel with that of Hanover. The Ruhr area was an important center of the German iron industry for some time and Thuringia was affected by these heavy industries.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage." Each of the plumage is associated with specific life cycle events; some plumes (those associated with nesting and brooding) develop prior to breeding and are shed following fledging or the nesting period, the underwing plumes (associated with flight) form over the course of the year and become more prominent during the breeding season, the head plumes develop on the crown around the time the birds emerge from the ground after hatching, and the shoulder plumes form just prior to emergence from the ground.

Eggs
The eggs of a number of bird species are brightly coloured. The eggs of many waterfowl species, such as mallards, have yellow, orange or creamy-white colours and may become pinkish as the bird ages due to the development of a red-brown pigmentation pattern on the eggs

Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern Scotland (where the Vikings called their settlements Dun Carloway, Dún Críoch, or Crich), the southeast coasts of England (where they called it 'Anglia') and at Chester. On the northern coast of Ireland, Viking raiders, led by the Norwegian Ivar the Boneless, laid waste large parts of the Scottish coast in the late 9th century, and in England they attacked the coastal areas of Yorkshire and Northumberland. The only known Viking settlement in Ireland, at Lough Foyle (see below), is a rather late-coming venture in the early 10th century.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these free radicals are scavenged by free radical-capturing enzyme systems. However, free radicals can overwhelm the antioxidant capacity of cells by acting in a non-specific manner to produce reactive oxygen species (i.e., superoxide radicals anion; ROS, hydroxyl radicals (HO^•^) (Figure [1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}), which then damage all biomolecules (e.g., lipids, proteins, and DNA-DNA, resulting, in turn, in irreversible cell loss) (Yamamoto et al., [@B55]). To illustrate, consider the following argument: if'_a_'refers to a certain specific physical object, which may not be present now, then the following statements are true: 1. A physical object _a_ is identical with (or at least similar to) itself. We do not have to make an assertion about a past object, as this was identical with it. Therefore, if'_a_'refers to a past object it is not a proposition about that object, and hence the identity and similarity operators are invalid. The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by Chinese polities of the ancient Zhou culture. These included several independent groups, including the state of Chu and several large tribal confederations, such as the Shangjun (; Duchy) and the Wudu () tribes, who shared a common culture for about 4,000 years.

The name Zhou is sometimes also used to refer to the ruling dynasty within the various Zhou states, the Zhou Dynasty proper. This is an imprecise usage since after their original defeat by the Shang, the kingdom and people were known for over two centuries as the State of Shang, "the Land Formerly Known as Shang".

Chu was the earliest empire in East Asia, although the exact time of its foundation is not known with any precision. The earliest date given is 1046 BC, but other dates are also possible. Chu

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed on by owls, and the predators in turn may be preyed on by raptors like eagles and falcons. A predator may take an advantage of this by being the top predator in its ecosystem, having some niche value. This is often related to their size, though even a species which falls below a predator's natural prey may be taken advantage of. Large predatory species may be more efficient than their smaller counterparts at bringing down their prey, and may kill or significantly injure predators with similar or greater size as long as this advantage is maintained. While it may be a useful strategy for an organism to appear smaller and less threatening in the absence of food, this can sometimes backfire if a species is unable to find another potential food source.

Predator-prey equilibrium can often be characterized by the relationship between predator-prey

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse could hear house music through a radio playing electronic music that was broadcast through the club's sound system by John Peel, who helped popularize house music in Britain during the early 1980s. House music was further popularized around the world in the early to mid-1980s by the "house movement"; artists and producers, like Derrick May (Key-Life) and Robert Sledge (Harmony), created a new genre of house music specifically aimed at dancers, later described as "powerfully rhythmic and euphoric". The first artists to perform house music in the clubs in both America and Britain were a group of musicians and musicians who worked on the music industry side of things that included DJs such as Frankie Bones, Kevin Saunderson, Danny K, Mark Moore, Nick Shorland and Kenny Larkin.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century.

The Byzantine Empire under Justinian, the sixth and penultimate Roman Emperor, saw significant geographical expansion. Justinian's reign in Byzantium (from 527–565) was marked by the conquest of Africa, Italy, Sicily, Corsica, Sardinia, Croatia, Dalmatia, Albania, the Peloponnese, and the Balkans, making the Byzantines the first European force to lay claim to them. This military success made possible a major religious revival among the Eastern Orthodox Christians, who had suffered from a "Great Schism" with their Western counterparts and also had their traditional religion being suppressed. From that point forward, the Orthodox Christian world centered on Byzantine and Latin Christianity in communion. Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. Their creation marked a high point in the evolution of mosaic designs; however, the quality of the non-religious mosaics was generally inferior to that of the religious mosaics. Examples of these works can be seen on several buildings in various places.

Mosaics from the time of the early Abbasids were of relatively poor quality, and often of a plain design, although exceptions can be found (such as the palace at the House of Wisdom in Baghdad). The quality of non-religious mosaics increased during the period of the Almohads and there is a considerable amount of interesting work available.

The title of "world's oldest airport" is disputed, but College Park Airport in Maryland, US, established in 1909 by Wilbur Wright, is the oldest continually operating airport in the United States. A recent count found over 150 civilian airports in operation, with five being active since World War I.

The first aircraft used in air transport was the tethered glider made by the brothers Antoine-Laurent Lavoisier, Louis-Pierre Vieyra, and Claude Antoine Vieyra and later designed by the brothers Jacques Charles and Gabriel Aubry.

Other early aviation pioneers included Henri Giffard, Octave Chanute, Louis Paulhan, Gustave Moilliet, Louis Blériot, Joseph Bouchard, and Samuel P. D'Arcy. While none of these early aircraft attained widespread use, they pioneered new ideas on aircraft design, including the aileron to counteract tail-first motion, aircraft engines, and the tailwheel.

By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike first to secure southern Germany. This plan proved to be his greatest blunder. He was forced to send another army to Italy to face a growing threat from the Austrians. In both cases, the initial attack proved to be a strategic failure.

The Campaign of 1799

In May 1799, when the Emperor moved through Switzerland and Italy, he had a good position. Austria was divided, her government was ineffective, the French force that was in Italy was not sufficient to threaten Austria’s eastern flank, and the allies in the north of Italy, the Kingdom of Sardinia, and the Papal States were weak. Indeed, the French army only had the forces gathered into several strong corps under Marshals Joubert, Mortier and Suchet. Napoleon had little chance of invading the continent without success.

One of the notable authors of esoteric interpretation prior to the 12th century is Sulami (d. 1021) without whose work the majority of very early interpretations would have been virtually impossible. He is considered one of the foremost teachers of a path to knowledge within Sufism. For example, Raza Ali Akbar wrote that Sulami "was the foremost of Sufi teachers in the twelfth century."

Among those who have studied his work it is agreed that Sulami had much in common with Ibn Arabi, and he is said to have had an "incalculable influence on the development of Islamic thought."

Sulami's Sufi works, collected under the general name Furu'l Hayat (The Delights of Life), form the foundation of a large body of esoteric teachings.

The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most lucrative markets, and from about that time, the colonies sought new markets. 

In 1785, the Board of Trade was looking into how best to utilize British colonies and the potential of their resources for British needs and interests. They held an "East India Company's Trade Inquiry" at the home of Lord Berkeley (Lord of the Manor of Berkeley Castle) in Gloucestershire on 3 July 1785, where they heard about new and old methods of commerce and how to further British interests. These methods included the British Empire, both old and new, the North West India Company, and the India Company. The outcome of the inquiry was that they needed to better integrate colonial markets for Britain. They concluded that the West Indies, West Africa, West Europe, South America, and North America were the best areas for the British Empire to expand

On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for the Arab and Jewish states of Palestine. On 12 May 1948, violence erupted between Jewish forces on the coastal plain of Palestine and Arab resistance fighters in neighboring Arab Mandatory areas of Palestine. This violence created a de facto partition of Mandatory Palestine. The Arab Higher Committee, comprising the governments of Arab countries, declared this conflict a war of independence against the existing Provisional State of Israel. However and even in spite of this declaration, most Arab States and states had in fact remained neutral on the war and as stated by their governments were not involved in any military action between the Jewish forces and the Arab resistance movements and in fact had not decided for or against a Jewish state either. For this reason, the majority of the Arab League members who had declared war on the Jewish state became known as the Arab states of Palestine.

In response to attribution of recent climate change, the City of Melbourne, in 2002, set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020 and to zero carbon emissions by 2050. This target was based on the City’s energy-related energy use as being the largest contributor to energy emissions in the City and on the City’s commitment to meet national and international commitments to reduce emissions. To support the target, Melbourne City Council established the Melbourne Energy Efficiency Partnership (MEEP) to oversee Melbourne’s energy efficiency performance. Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian (the language of a region in which Valencia is located) is an official co-official language in Valencia itself. Like any European city, English is also used sometimes. The official language of both companies and institutions is Valencian. However, Spanish is used for official documents, as well as some types of advertising such as posters and the like. Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a revolution, which she had neither caused nor desired, is now obliged to become her own protector." Although he expressed concern, he thought only the guillotine, to be introduced soon, was to be feared. At his instigation, Parliament passed the Alien Act and the Declaratory Act. These declared the colonists' right to hold their property and gave legal weight to the notion that the colonies and parent country were separate political entities; the same principle was affirmed in the U.S. Constitution of 1787, a year before the first meeting of the French National Assembly. Burke's ideas, however, had a profound effect on the colonies; without them, they might have made other revolutions or continued to be "squeaky wheels" in a union of sovereign states.

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old. The first evidence of human use of copper was on the Great Wall of China and archaeological excavations have shown evidence of use of copper by the Minoans in Greece, the Egyptians, the Romans and the Britons, amongst others. Copper is one of the most common minerals found in the Earth's crust. The discovery that gold and copper could be mined on the surface of the earth (known as surface mining) led to widespread use of both during the Middle Ages. Copper is usually found in the oxidation state of the +2 oxidation state, although much of it occurs in the +1 oxidation state as CuO. Copper oxide occurs as green or blue oxides[9] and sometimes also as blue arsenates.[10]

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, near Whitby in North Yorkshire, which is just under 50m above mean sea level. In general, the western seaboard of Britain and Ireland is more exposed to marine flooding and erosion, and islands to the east, where the rivers are meandering channels, are more likely to have been formed in or on floodplains or landwards.

Although most of the islands have only a relatively brief history, in the last 10,000 years the islands are estimated to have suffered flooding at intervals. Many islands are still subject to marine flooding when the sea levels rise during an Ice Age glacial period. Although much of Europe and a number of smaller islands were inundated during the last Ice Age, for reasons not fully understood, only Ireland and Iceland appear to have suffered widespread inundation. The effects of some of these may still be apparent

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs 15 to 30 minutes after a meal, and the gastric phase is initiated at the time of gastric emptying. The intestinal phase begins as the food leaves the stomach and food passes into the small intestine. Foods containing protein digest slower than foods without protein, such as carbohydrates or fat.

The gastric phase begins when gastric juices release pepsin and hydrochloric acid. Pepsin begins to digest proteins and hydrochloric acid begins to digest carbohydrates, starches, and fats. At a pH of 1.0 or lower, hydrochloric acid is inactivated. About 20 minutes to an hour after eating is the second phase of gastric digestion, which begins with the release of lipase and salivary amylase from the pancreas. The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and sometimes unintentionally) as the planet’s human population continues to grow and the need for food, fuel, building materials, and other resources intensifies. For humans, it feels like a new species invasion every day — and for nonhuman species, like birds and tortoises? Well, no. Birds, reptiles, amphibians, and other creatures from all over the world have been appearing in and invading the United States by the thousands during the 20th century.

A new report by the National Avian Research and Documentation Center and the National Wildlife Federation looks at the extent of these invasions and how they’ve affected life in the continental United States over the last hundred years. The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the bleachers behind home plate, and many of which are from the surrounding area.

History

The roots of the fan culture of rooting for the home players can be traced back to the 19th Century, when it was commonplace to watch games from the stands to which the stadium wasn't built, and when cheering for a player was the only way to communicate with them. It was thought that such fans would be called "bleacher bums." It became a part of major league baseball when the leagues began playing indoor games which were much more difficult to follow than outdoor games, since the stands were built for the game and fans couldn't see as much.

Now, with no one sitting on the stands, "bleachers" has lost some of the traditional meaning of a place where fans can sit together, cheer loudly, and sometimes even chant

Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current where the tram floor would rise above the third rail in the usual collection mode, or at least the last few feet of the tram where the car floor was at street level. The tram dropped to a near-touching low voltage (LV) pickup near the next crossover or where the car floor went below the third rail. The third rail power would be turned off just below the tram’s floor or below floor of the collection region, or as otherwise described in the tram’s operating manual.

In most older street trams, there would be a third rail pickup switch for the collector and a near-touching switch for the converter, as well as a “safety switch” that would disconnect the third rail from the tram in the event of a collision.

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the fact that the phonautograph recorded the sounds a speaker produced, the first recordings made on Edison’s phonograph proved to have little use beyond being amusing noveltys (Edwards and K. Edwards, 2009).

By 1899, in the year the first public demonstration of the phonograph was held, the Edison Company had spent half a million dollars (and a total of three million in various patents) on research and development and had made almost 100 patented inventions (Smith, 2003, p. 17). The introduction of the phonograph opened up an entirely new form of entertainment: recorded music.

Recorded music became a significant part of popular culture in the early twentieth century following the arrival of the commercially manufactured recording machine. The popularity of recorded music grew throughout the early half of the twentieth century and this growth seemed to continue unabated

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch. Graecus has his own entry in the Catalogue and is called "Graecus, son of Zeus, son of Hellen, son of Enyalius". The epithets Graecus and Graeci were commonly used in classical antiquity to refer to the Greeks themselves, but may be applied as well to individuals who lived in Greece or spoke the Attic dialect:

The epithet Graecus was used also by other authors besides Hesiod; for instance by Demosthenes (c. 384-322 BC). But it seems that the name Graecus was specially appropriate to the Hellenic race which Hesiod refers to as Graeci in the Catalogue. In the Epitaphs of Maenads it has the additional meaning of the name of the people of Aegina.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and maintenance. For example, in the brain it is released in the form of neurotransmitters that regulate the body's state of consciousness; when released into the body in the form of glucose it is responsible for the body's energy needs; and when emitted in the form of heat it is responsible for the body's temperature control.
An additional source of energy is the organism's interaction with its environment. For example, for a human being it is produced by chemical interactions such as oxidation of foodstuffs, reduction of atmospheric oxygen, oxidation of hemoglobin, lactic acid fermentation by microorganism, etc.
Since such energy is needed by all living organisms, it can be described as "universal energy" since it is needed by all living organisms. Therefore, only living organisms, or inanimate life-like systems such as biocomputing devices

From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by Thomas McWilliams. On one occasion, McWilliams and a few confederates held up a stagecoach that was carrying $5,000 to $10,000 in cash. For his part in the crime, McWilliams received an unusually light jail sentence - a total of ten years, to be served on the chain gang, but the sentence was later commuted by President Benjamin Harrison. There were no further incidents and McWilliams was released and returned to his work as an itinerant peddler, as was typical of his time and place.

During that time, the ruling dynasty, the Umayyad Caliphate, promoted the Hanafi school of Islamic Jurisprudence at the expense of the Shafi’ite school. A century later, the caliph, Umar, who came to be known as a strict law-giver, issued his fatwa against Shi’ism as a heresy from the Hanafi school. He said “It is not permitted to follow the path of the Shi’ites in their rejection of the first three caliphs (Abu Bakr, Omar, Uthman), the Sunni tradition and the Hanafi scholars, or to allow more than three of them to be present in congregational prayer”.

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by the figure of Christ. This image had a long history, from Roman, Byzantine, Lombard, Burgundian and Carolingian art in the 4th, 5th and 6th centuries. But it acquired a new life after Charlemagne's court moved from Aachen to the newly completed palaces of the newly-founded imperial capitals at Aachen and Ingelheim. Carolingian art was given a new life through Carolingian patronage, which made it accessible to ordinary people, not just the wealthy.

Carolingian painting and sculpture had two principal centres : the workshops of Liège and Aachen, and the workshops of Tours. But artists were also active at Poitiers, Rome, Lyons, Mainz, Soissons, Reims, Ghent, Tournai, Cambra

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid were so widely and so soon widely known by Latin poets (who knew only the Georgics anyway), partly by the wide influence of the Greek version, that they became the standard models for a long and vital poetic period in Rome. Virgil's work was never only the classical past of Rome – for Romans it already became not only a present but for all, a future. He thus founded a tradition which is present throughout the history of Latin literature.

But Rome had much wider experience to assimilate and to influence. Latin literature, as we have seen, grew up in direct contact with Greek culture, particularly in poetry and rhetoric. The classical language itself was derived from Greek. In Latin, as in Greek, words tended to form compounds. It was probably for this reason that Latin poets were later fond of using Latin words that

By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). Under the Peshwas, the empire became an economic and military powerhouse with a major trading network that connected across South India, Southeast Asia, East Africa, and the Arabian Peninsula as well as the Red Sea coast. At the end of the 18th century, the Maratha kingdom disintegrated after the death of Peshwa Baji Rao I and his successor ended its rule of India. With the fall of the empire after 150 years of control, the Maratha heritage went into obscurity.

It was not until the 19th century that the Maratha story again came to the fore. The Maratha Empire disintegrated because of the inability of the Peshwas to lead their people effectively. It was not just Peshwas who were responsible for the downfall of the empire, but also their advisors, the Brahmins, who tried to manipulate the power structure

Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, and Church Slavic, respectively) have had different social status from one another. While Church Slavic was and is still the language of the Church, Chakavian and Kajkavian are still widely used as local languages. Additionally, Church Slavic, originally the liturgical language in the Church, is also the language of instruction for children. The usage of these languages in the schools is not the same as that of their parents but they can be used in schoolwork. Thus, in many Serbian areas of the former Yugoslavia, the local dialect is taught in schools as an international language, alongside Church Slavic.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury. The Soviets had launched a spacecraft named Zond, intended to rendezvous with an unmanned probe the previous year. The Soviets had also successfully launched the first interplanetary spacecraft, a test of their new Venera series of rocket.

The Americans were now waiting for another launch, which would be the first to put an astronaut into orbit. They were convinced that they were only a few months away from success.

On May 5, 1959, the Soviet Union launched a space capsule called Vostok, putting an American astronaut in orbit for the first time.

The event was a historical turning point in space exploration, marking a triumph of the socialist system over the capitalist world, as well as another example of how the Soviet Union could keep up with new technologies. While the United States had long been an active player in early

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the central mountains rise to 583 m); there are also extensive grasslands in the valleys. The island was formed some 600,000 years ago when a volcanic eruption created a huge caldera (a volcanic depression surrounded by a rim of craters containing some of the ejecta) 2 mi across and 600 m deep, which filled with sea water before the subsequent uplift of the land, so that the current landscape resembles a bowl at the bottom of a deep crater. As a result of the volcanic activity over the past 6,000 years, the island's volcanic rocks are composed of a series of overlapping tuffs that contain large crystals of zircon and rutiles. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch 78 RPM discs. By April 1938, he was recording for the new 4-inch (100 RPM) LP record format.

On the first Commodore pressings, Milt made use of a number of instruments that were popular for studio work, such as guitar, a harmonium, organ, upright piano, a bass and flute.

The first 45rpm vinyl release came in 1949, after the first release of the original, single-disc LP format in 1943. However, due to supply issues, the early 45rpm releases were only single 12-inch records.

In late 1945, the Victor subsidiary RCA bought the rights to the popular 45rpm format in order to create the first "Compact Disc".

However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a ball with the same force in the two palms. Such asymmetry can only be explained if we can take as an example a normal human being dropping two similar balls with unequal force, and also an abnormal individual dropping a ball with equal force in the two palms. The normal case shows the asymmetry for which causality is an asymmetry of _force_, not an asymmetry of _time_. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the New York State Legislature enacted that an area extending to the southern border of Massachusetts known as the Great Meadow, and including modern-day Long Island, would be given to the state and its new citizens. The land was eventually annexed by New York after the Civil War.

During the War of 1812 the state was an ally of the United States and supplied men and ships to aid the defense. There were fears that the British would invade the coast. New York did not have a state navy as Massachusetts did but a series of ships were built under the supervision of Commodore Isaac Hull. The two-funneled, schooner USS Constitution was among the first ship-fitted warships and the first iron-hulled warship to use such a design.

On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 564 artillery batteries against 72 artillery batteries and 715 infantry battalions of the Army of Loigny-Poupry. The French attack started from three directions: the left wing attacked up the slopes from the valley, the center from the south and the right wing attacked to the east.

The French forces captured all positions, capturing the village of Poupry. The French infantry suffered only 10 officers and 53 NCO casualties and 19 men, and the artillery only 1 officer and 7 NCO casualties. French losses in men were over 5,000, of which 3,500 were casualties, while the Germans lost only 400 men.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between the pope and the king. Edward did not take kindly to the move and had John arrested. John was detained at Hertford Castle, guarded by the royal constables. However the castle was besieged on the orders of his son-in-law Thomas Gurney, the Archbishop of York, who sought to use his influence to secure John's release. The news travelled quickly through England. John remained in custody for several weeks.

Thomas Gurney had gained a reputation for piety and learning through his work with King Edward. Gurney is said to have converted John's guard, Stephen, a soldier in the king's household, by offering him the sacraments. Gurney also arranged for John to hold mass for his captives. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep. A single point in Canadian football is worth 7 points (6 in American football) and two points each for a touchdown, extra point and field goal. (This point scoring system originated at the time of Dominion, when a point was worth one-sixth of a dollar, so Canadian values of points are actually somewhat larger.) The Canadian Football Hall of Fame and Museum at Saint Mary's (Hal) University in Halifax, Nova Scotia holds the official Canadian Football Record Book, which is the standard source for statistics.
The first Canadian Football League team, the Ottawa Rough Riders, played from 1873 until 1960 and are the only team to have played continuously (except for the two World Wars). In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis powers.  The list included some 1,000 names, including that of Dr. Richard Evans, a radiologist in the Los Angeles area.  He had been called before the House Committee on Un-American Activities and refused to reveal the names of communists in his laboratory.  He was arrested in 1939 and held in custody for eighteen months prior to being released under heavy bail.

South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-hee, the former president’s wife, and Hwang Jang-yop, former director of Korea’s national sports commission, were named as the two relay runners. A total of about 20 torch-bearers and relay runners from all over the world participated. They travelled to Seoul by plane, from the torch relay venues in three regional capitals: Busan in the south, Nagoya in Central Japan and Jakarta in Southeast Asia. More than 7 billion people in more than 200 countries and islands around the globe are reported to have watched the relay on live television broadcasts. (Reported by Kim Dae-young, Seoul; writing by Christine Kim)

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and is still continuing. The practice of breeding and raising animals for commercial and personal consumption is a relatively recent development in modern times. Until comparatively recent times, the practice of breeding animals for milk production, sport, egg-laying or companionship in the home, or for consumption, either directly by human beings or by consumption by animals, was largely limited to the use of animals in religious cults or by people on a small scale. In such circumstances, only relatively small numbers of animals were available for such work. However, the development of technology in the twentieth century, particularly in the latter half of the century and since the 1970's, has brought about major changes.

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is a form of skepticism, that is, “the belief in a God, the denial of any revelation, and the rejection of any organized religion.”1 If atheists don’t believe in God or in a God-centered universe, then how can they be skeptical?

Some writers even suggested that skepticism was incompatible with religious belief. One writer referred to atheism as “the great enemy of the soul.”2 However, atheism, or agnosticism, is not necessarily the problem; it’s the belief in an omnipotent, omniscient, sovereign God that is the problem. But then what is religion?

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph)), and most humid (72.4 percent). The climate does not take into account the effect of the Gulf Stream that blows down from the continent, but rather its proximity to it. It is generally cold during the winter months and, as the only northernmost city in the Maritimes, cool during the summer too. Despite this, St. John's weather is generally mild as the region's moderating influence of these two great bodies of water is felt all year round.

As of 2004, the city has the second-most humid climate in Canada and the 10th-most humid in the world. Even after Hurricane Igor in 2007 and Hurricane Tomas in May 2008, the city was spared from the heavy rains associated with both storms.

Many scholars call this period a time when “the Irish came of age.” As historian Philip McCaffrey notes, “Notre Dame, because of its large student body and campus size, because of its sports program and alumni network, because of its proximity to America’s ethnic melting-pot area—Brooklyn, for instance—becomes a sort of a town in its own right, a home-like locale full of clubs and organizations, clubs and alumni affairs, clubs and so on. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas. These are the Alps, the Jura and the Alps and Jura, which are connected by the Rhine (Rhein) Valley, the Gotthard/Swiss railway, and the Gotthard Tunnel. The highest point is located in the north and is Mount Blanc (Monte Bianco); it is over 3,500 m (11,340 ft) high. This mountain range is one of the largest in the Alps. Switzerland is located near the geographical center of Europe. A few thousand years ago, the present-day Switzerland was occupied by the Celts, but at that date, Switzerland had a totally different shape (Figure 1.1).

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm as a surrogate for actual annual minimum temperature one may arrive at the following definition for the "Dry Month".

Definition: Dry Month

A Dry Month is any calendar month in which at least 0.50 of an inch (or 1.27 cm) or more of precipitation fell.

This 0.50 inch (or 1.27 cm) threshold was chosen because 0.50 of an inch falls roughly every 7 to 20 days. Note that 0.50 of an inch is roughly a 1/3 cup over the course of 7 to 20 days (depending on elevation, wind speed, etc.).

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that women did not have to cover their heads, hands and feet or be veiled came to be entrenched in the legal codes under the Abbasids. It followed that in principle the madrasa was free to continue the same without any legal restraint so long as it did not affect other students. This had the advantage of being both cheap and simple as long as the madrasa did not require too large of a staff size at any one time. There were thus a very large number of private madrasa in the 11th century. However, in the 12th century the Abbasid caliph al-Nasir al-Dawla decreed the closing of all Sunni madrasa. Madrasa were closed as they had not yet been fully established.
